cities.name: Medellín
cities.summary: Medellín has transformed from one of the world's most dangerous cities into a thriving hub for tourists and digital nomads. Most visitors have safe, enjoyable trips — but the city still requires awareness. Petty crime, scams, and neighborhood-specific risks are real. Here's everything you need to know.
cities.quickVerdict: Medellín is safe for tourists who stick to well-known areas and exercise common-sense precautions. El Poblado, Laureles, and Envigado are your safest bets. The biggest risks are petty theft, drink spiking (scopolamine), and taxi scams — not violent crime. Don't flash expensive items, use ride-hailing apps instead of street taxis, and never accept drinks or food from strangers.

neighborhoods.name: El Poblado
neighborhoods.description: The main tourist hub. Parque Lleras, Provenza, and the Golden Mile are well-patrolled. Biggest risk is petty theft and drink spiking in nightlife areas. Safe to walk during the day; stick to main streets at night.

neighborhoods.name: Laureles
neighborhoods.description: Slightly more local feel than Poblado. La 70 street has great restaurants and nightlife. Safer at night than Poblado in many ways because there's less tourist-targeting crime.

neighborhoods.name: Envigado
neighborhoods.description: Quiet, residential, and very safe. Feels more authentically Colombian. Great food scene around Parque Envigado. Less nightlife but lower crime rates.

neighborhoods.name: El Centro
neighborhoods.description: Bustling downtown with incredible culture but high pickpocket risk. Visit during the day for Botero Plaza and markets. Avoid after dark.

neighborhoods.name: Comuna 13
neighborhoods.description: Famous for street art and transformation story. Safe for daytime guided tours on the main graffiti routes. Don't wander off the tourist path or visit after 4pm.

neighborhoods.name: Castilla / Aranjuez
neighborhoods.description: Not tourist areas. Higher crime rates, gang presence in some blocks. No reason for tourists to visit. Take an Uber out if you end up here.

scams.name: Scopolamine (Devil's Breath)
scams.description: A drug that renders victims compliant and unable to remember what happened. Administered through spiked drinks, blown powder, laced paper, or perfume samples.
scams.howToAvoid: Never accept drinks from strangers. Don't take flyers or paper from people on the street. Cover your drink at all times. Be cautious with dating app matches who suggest specific bars.

scams.name: Dating App Robbery
scams.description: Attractive profiles on Tinder, Bumble, and Instagram arrange to meet tourists, then spike drinks or lead them to locations where accomplices rob them.
scams.howToAvoid: Meet in public places only. Never go to a stranger's apartment on a first meeting. Tell a friend where you're going.

scams.name: Fake Police Officers
scams.description: Scammers in police-like uniforms stop tourists and demand to inspect wallets, claiming to look for counterfeit bills. They pocket cash during inspection.
scams.howToAvoid: Real Colombian police will never ask to see your wallet on the street. Suggest going to the nearest CAI (police station) together.

scams.name: Overcharging Taxis
scams.description: Some drivers run rigged meters, take long routes, or refuse to use the meter and demand inflated prices.
scams.howToAvoid: Use Uber, InDriver, or DiDi. If using a taxi, confirm the meter is running. Airport to El Poblado should be ~35,000–50,000 COP.

soloFemale.overview: Medellín is visited by many solo female travelers and most have positive experiences. Catcalling is common outside tourist areas. The biggest specific risk is drink spiking — women are disproportionately targeted.

cities.name: Mexico City
cities.summary: Mexico City is massive, complex, and rewarding. With over 21 million people in the metro area, it's a city of extreme contrasts. Roma, Condesa, and Polanco are as safe as many European neighborhoods. Other colonias carry real risks. The key is knowing where you are at all times.
cities.quickVerdict: Mexico City is safe in the right neighborhoods with standard precautions. Stay in Roma, Condesa, Polanco, or Coyoacán. Use Uber instead of street taxis (this is critical). Don't flash valuables, be aware of your surroundings, and you'll likely have an amazing trip. The food alone is worth it.

neighborhoods.name: Coyoacán

scams.howToAvoid: Never hail taxis from the street — this is the #1 rule in Mexico City. Always use Uber, DiDi, or a sitio (taxi stand) called by your hotel.

scams.name: Fake Uber / Taxi
scams.description: Someone approaches at the airport or busy areas claiming to be your Uber. They're not. Could lead to robbery or overcharging at minimum.
scams.howToAvoid: Always verify the license plate, car model, and driver name match your app before getting in. Never accept rides from people who approach you.

scams.name: ATM Skimming

scams.howToAvoid: Use ATMs inside banks during business hours. Cover the keypad. Avoid standalone ATMs in convenience stores. Check for loose card readers.

cities.name: Bangkok
cities.summary: Bangkok is one of the safest major cities in Southeast Asia for tourists. Violent crime against foreigners is extremely rare. The real risks are scams, petty theft, and traffic accidents. Millions visit safely every year, but the sheer density of tourist-targeting scams means you need to stay sharp.
cities.quickVerdict: Bangkok is safe for most travelers. Violent crime is very low — your biggest concerns are tuk-tuk scams, gem shop cons, overpriced everything, and the occasional pickpocket in crowded areas. Use the BTS/MRT, be skeptical of anyone approaching you near tourist sites, and you'll be fine.

neighborhoods.name: Sukhumvit
neighborhoods.description: Main expat and tourist corridor. Well-lit, tons of restaurants, BTS accessible. Nana and Asoke areas have red-light activity but are safe to walk through.

neighborhoods.name: Silom / Sathorn
neighborhoods.description: Business district by day, nightlife hub by night. Patpong night market area has aggressive touts but low crime. Well-connected by BTS and MRT.

neighborhoods.name: Old City (Rattanakosin)
neighborhoods.description: Where the Grand Palace, Wat Pho, and Khao San Road are. Safe but heavy tourist scam territory. Be skeptical of anyone telling you attractions are 'closed today'.

neighborhoods.name: Khao San Road
neighborhoods.description: Backpacker hub. Safe but chaotic. Drink spiking happens, bags get snatched, and bucket drinks can be dangerously strong. Keep valuables secure.

neighborhoods.name: Chinatown (Yaowarat)
neighborhoods.description: Incredible street food scene. Crowded and chaotic but generally safe. Watch for pickpockets in the dense market areas. Best visited in the evening.

neighborhoods.name: Klong Toei
neighborhoods.description: Contains Bangkok's largest slum. Not a tourist area. Drug activity and occasional violence. No reason to visit unless with a reputable NGO tour.

scams.name: Grand Palace 'Closed Today'
scams.description: Friendly strangers near tourist sites tell you the attraction is closed for a holiday/ceremony and offer to take you to a 'special' temple or shop instead. You end up at a gem shop or tailor with massive markups.
scams.howToAvoid: The Grand Palace is almost never closed unexpectedly. Ignore anyone approaching you outside who claims otherwise. Walk directly to the entrance.

scams.name: Tuk-Tuk Tour Scam
scams.description: Tuk-tuk drivers offer suspiciously cheap rides (10-20 baht) but take you to gem shops, tailors, and travel agencies where they earn commission from your purchases.
scams.howToAvoid: If the price seems too good to be true, it is. Use Grab (ride-hailing app) or metered taxis instead. If you want a tuk-tuk experience, negotiate a fixed price for a specific destination.

scams.name: Gem Shop Scam
scams.description: You're told about a 'government gem sale' or 'once-a-year export opportunity.' The gems are worthless glass sold at massive markups. Often connected to tuk-tuk scams.
scams.howToAvoid: There is no government gem sale. Never buy gems from shops you were taken to. If you want gems, research reputable dealers independently.

scams.name: Jet Ski Damage Scam
scams.description: More common in beach areas like Pattaya and Phuket, but also at river activities in Bangkok. Operators claim you damaged the jet ski and demand thousands of baht.
scams.howToAvoid: Photograph/video the equipment before and after use. Avoid jet ski rentals from operators without clear rental agreements. Have your hotel recommend reputable operators.

soloFemale.overview: Bangkok is one of the safer Asian cities for solo female travelers. Thai culture is generally respectful, and violent crime against women tourists is rare. The main risks are the same scams that affect everyone, plus some unwanted attention in nightlife areas.
tips: Bangkok is very welcoming to solo female travelers — many women travel here alone without issues
Dress modestly when visiting temples (cover shoulders and knees) — this is cultural respect, not just safety
Be cautious in Khao San Road area late at night — drink spiking does occur
Use Grab (Southeast Asia's Uber) rather than hailing random taxis, especially at night
Full moon party areas and Patpong can feel aggressive — you can avoid them entirely without missing much
Thai people are generally helpful — if you feel uncomfortable, duck into any 7-Eleven (they're everywhere) and ask staff for help

cities.name: Cape Town
cities.summary: Cape Town is one of the most beautiful cities on Earth — and one that requires genuine caution. Tourist areas like the V&A Waterfront and Camps Bay are safe, but Cape Town has extreme inequality and the crime that comes with it. The city rewards informed visitors with unforgettable experiences, but going in naive can lead to serious problems.
cities.quickVerdict: Cape Town is safe in tourist areas with proper precautions, but requires more awareness than most Western cities. Stick to known safe areas, don't walk alone at night outside tourist zones, use Uber exclusively, and don't display valuables. The beauty is absolutely worth the extra vigilance.

neighborhoods.description: The safest area in Cape Town. Shopping, restaurants, private security. Safe to walk around day and night within the complex. Essentially a self-contained safe zone.

neighborhoods.description: Affluent beachside suburb. Very safe, beautiful sunsets, good restaurants. Safe to walk during the day. Don't leave valuables visible in parked cars.

neighborhoods.description: Popular promenade for walking and jogging. Safe during the day, okay early evening. Don't walk the promenade alone after dark. Good restaurants along the strip.

neighborhoods.name: Woodstock
neighborhoods.description: Gentrifying arts district. Great during the day for markets and galleries. Borders rougher areas — don't wander too far from the main streets. Uber in and out.

neighborhoods.description: Extremely dangerous. High gang activity, shootings, and violent crime. Absolutely no reason for tourists to go here. This includes Khayelitsha, Nyanga, and Mitchell's Plain unless on a reputable guided township tour.

scams.name: Car Break-ins
scams.description: Anything visible in your car will be stolen — guaranteed. Smash-and-grab at traffic lights also happens. Thieves watch parking lots and strike quickly.
scams.howToAvoid: Never leave anything visible in your car. Use the trunk before arriving at your destination (not while being watched). Keep windows up and doors locked at traffic lights.

scams.name: Fake Parking Attendants
scams.description: Unofficial car guards demand payment for 'watching' your car. Some are legitimate informal workers, others are not. Refusing can occasionally lead to your car being vandalized.
scams.howToAvoid: Give R5-R10 to avoid trouble — it's not worth the conflict. Use secure parking garages when possible. Some areas have legitimate city-appointed car guards with vests.

scams.name: Mugging at Scenic Spots
scams.description: Isolated scenic viewpoints and hiking trails (Signal Hill, Lion's Head, Table Mountain paths) are targeted by muggers, especially early morning and late afternoon.
scams.howToAvoid: Hike in groups, never alone. Start popular hikes when others are around. Don't carry expensive cameras/phones visibly. Stick to well-trafficked paths.

scams.name: Beach Theft
scams.description: Belongings left on the beach while swimming are stolen quickly. Organized thieves watch for distracted tourists.
scams.howToAvoid: Never leave bags unattended on the beach. Use a waterproof pouch for phone and cards. Take turns watching belongings.

soloFemale.overview: Solo female travel in Cape Town requires extra precautions compared to European cities. The tourist areas are fine, but South Africa has high rates of gender-based violence. Staying aware and choosing safe areas makes a huge difference.

Always use Uber — never walk alone at night outside the Waterfront or Camps Bay strip
Join group tours for hiking and township visits
Don't walk between neighborhoods — Uber even for short distances
The Waterfront is the safest area for evening dining and entertainment

tips: V&A Waterfront is safe to walk around at night — private security is everywhere
Camps Bay main strip is safe for evening dining

Do not walk between areas at night — even short distances

transport.rideshare: Uber is your best friend in Cape Town. Reliable, safe, and reasonably priced. Use it for everything, especially at night. Bolt also operates here.
transport.taxis: Metered taxis exist but are more expensive than Uber and less reliable. Don't hail from the street. Your hotel or restaurant can call a reputable company.
transport.tips: Uber for everything. Seriously. Don't rent a car unless you're doing the Garden Route or wine country day trips, and even then, lock everything in the trunk.

health.water: Tap water is safe to drink in Cape Town — some of the best municipal water in Africa.
health.vaccinations: No specific vaccinations required for Cape Town. Yellow fever certificate needed if arriving from an endemic country. Malaria is not a risk in Cape Town.
health.altitude: No altitude concerns. Sun is extremely strong — use high SPF sunscreen. The UV index regularly hits extreme levels.

faq.q: Is Cape Town safe for tourists?
faq.a: In tourist areas, yes — with precautions. The Waterfront, Camps Bay, and Constantia are safe. But Cape Town has stark inequality and high crime rates overall. Stay informed about which areas to avoid.

faq.q: Is Uber safe in Cape Town?

cities.name: Marrakech

soloFemale.overview: Istanbul is visited by many solo women and is generally safe. Turkish culture values hospitality, and locals are often genuinely helpful. However, catcalling and persistent male attention are more common than in Western Europe, particularly outside main tourist areas.

Use BiTaksi app rather than hailing taxis on the street at night

nightSafety.overview: Istanbul is generally safe at night in tourist and entertainment areas. İstiklal Avenue, Karaköy, and Kadıköy stay busy until late. The city has an active nightlife culture and well-lit main streets.

Avoid Tarlabaşı and back streets off İstiklal after dark

transport.metro: Istanbul's metro, tram, and ferry system is extensive and safe. Get an Istanbulkart (transit card) — it works on all public transport. The tram through Sultanahmet is excellent for tourists.
transport.rideshare: BiTaksi is the main ride-hailing app. Uber was banned but may return. BiTaksi shows you the fare upfront and is much safer than street taxis.
transport.taxis: Yellow taxis are everywhere but scams are common. Always insist on the meter and verify the rate setting. Airport transfers are better booked through BiTaksi or your hotel.
transport.tips: The ferry between European and Asian sides is one of the best transit experiences in the world — safe, cheap, and beautiful views.

health.overview: Istanbul has good private hospitals. Acibadem and Memorial are well-regarded. EU health insurance (EHIC) does not cover Turkey — travel insurance is important.
health.water: Tap water is technically safe but tastes heavily chlorinated. Most locals drink bottled or filtered water. Bottled water is very cheap.
health.vaccinations: No specific vaccinations required. Routine vaccines should be up to date. Hepatitis A recommended for longer stays.
health.altitude: No altitude concerns. Earthquake risk is real — Turkey sits on major fault lines. Know your hotel's evacuation plan.

faq.q: Is Istanbul safe for American tourists?
faq.a: Yes, Istanbul is safe for Americans. The US State Department rates Turkey at Level 2. Tourist areas are well-policed and millions of Americans visit without incident.

faq.q: Is Istanbul safe for solo female travelers?
faq.a: Generally yes, especially in tourist areas. Some unwanted male attention in more conservative neighborhoods, but violent incidents are very rare.
Yes, physically safe. But it's the prime pickpocket zone — keep valuables in front pockets and bags zipped. Vendors are persistent but not threatening.

faq.q: Should I worry about terrorism in Istanbul?
faq.a: Istanbul has experienced attacks in the past, but security has been significantly increased. Tourist areas are well-monitored. The risk is present but low.

faq.q: Is it safe to use public transport?
faq.a: Yes, very safe. The metro, tram, and ferries are clean and well-monitored. Rush hour can be extremely crowded — watch for pickpockets.

cities.name: Marseille
cities.summary: Marseille is France's grittiest major city — and its most authentic. The Vieux-Port is beautiful, the bouillabaisse legendary, and the Calanques national park stunning. It has real crime issues that tourists should be aware of, but the rewards are worth the extra vigilance.
cities.quickVerdict: Rougher than Paris or Nice but more authentic. Vieux-Port and La Joliette are tourist-friendly. Northern neighborhoods have serious crime. Don't flash valuables. The Calanques are paradise.

cities.name: Naples
cities.summary: Naples is raw, intense, and utterly authentic Italy. The best pizza on Earth. Pompeii and the Amalfi Coast are nearby. It's grittier than Rome or Florence — motorbike theft and petty crime are real. But the food, history, and energy are unmatched.
cities.quickVerdict: Grittier than northern Italy but incredibly rewarding. Centro Storico and waterfront are fine with awareness. Motorbike snatching is the main risk. The pizza is genuinely life-changing. Pompeii is a must.

cities.name: Tbilisi
cities.summary: Tbilisi is one of the safest capital cities in the world and one of the best-value destinations. Incredible food, legendary wine, ancient history, and the warmest hospitality. Crime against tourists is extremely rare. The biggest risk is eating and drinking too much.
cities.quickVerdict: Extremely safe. Walk the old town at 3am without worry. The food and wine are extraordinary. Incredibly affordable. One of the most underrated cities in the world.

cities.name: Amman
cities.summary: Amman is one of the safest cities in the Middle East. Jordan is a haven of stability. The city is the gateway to Petra, Wadi Rum, and the Dead Sea. Jordanian hospitality is legendary. Main challenges are taxi scams and some harassment for women.

cities.name: Dubai
cities.summary: Dubai is one of the safest cities in the world. Violent crime is essentially zero. The strict legal system and heavy surveillance keep crime extremely low. cities.name: Kathmandu
cities.summary: Kathmandu is the gateway to the Himalayas and a spiritual center. Thamel is the tourist hub — chaotic but safe. Nepal is one of the friendliest countries in Asia. Main risks are petty scams, altitude on treks, and earthquake vulnerability.
cities.quickVerdict: Safe and welcoming. Thamel is tourist base. Scams around trekking gear and tours are main issue. Altitude on Everest Base Camp and Annapurna treks is serious. The temples and mountains are extraordinary.

neighborhoods.name: Thamel
neighborhoods.description: Tourist hub. Gear shops, restaurants, bars. Safe but chaotic. Some tout hassle.

neighborhoods.name: Durbar Square area
neighborhoods.description: Ancient palace square. Still recovering from 2015 earthquake. Beautiful. Watch pickpockets.

neighborhoods.name: Patan (Lalitpur)
neighborhoods.description: Across the river. Stunning Durbar Square. Quieter and more charming than Thamel.

neighborhoods.name: Boudhanath
neighborhoods.description: Massive Buddhist stupa. Peaceful, safe, spiritual. Tibetan restaurants.

neighborhoods.name: Bhaktapur
neighborhoods.description: Medieval preserved city. Day trip. Very safe and atmospheric.

neighborhoods.name: Ring Road outskirts
neighborhoods.description: Less safe areas beyond tourist zone. Traffic chaos.

scams.name: Fake Trekking Gear
scams.description: Thamel full of counterfeit North Face, Mountain Hardwear. Looks real but fails in the mountains.
scams.howToAvoid: Bring crucial gear from home. Or buy knowing it's fake and bring backups.

scams.name: Unlicensed Trek Guides
scams.description: Cheap guides without proper training or insurance.
scams.howToAvoid: Use TAAN-registered agencies. Verify guide licenses. Don't go cheapest.

scams.name: Gem/Tiger Bone Scams
scams.description: Offered 'precious' items that are worthless.
scams.howToAvoid: Don't buy gems or animal products. Tiger bone sales are illegal.

scams.name: Taxi Overcharging
scams.description: No meters. Prices inflate for tourists.
scams.howToAvoid: Pathao or InDriver apps. Negotiate before riding.

soloFemale.overview: Nepal is one of the safest South Asian countries for solo women. Nepali culture is gentle and respectful. Thamel is comfortable. Solo trekking requires a guide (mandatory in some areas).
tips: Thamel is safe and easy for solo travelers
Guides now mandatory for most popular treks
Patan is quieter alternative to Thamel
Altitude is the real danger — acclimatize properly

nightSafety.overview: Thamel has bars and restaurants. Safe but some drunk tourists are the problem. Nepal has a 10pm curfew on some bars.
tips: Walking in Thamel fine at night

transport.metro: No metro. Chaotic roads.
transport.taxis: No meters. Negotiate first.
transport.tips: Pathao app for taxis. Walking in Thamel. Tourist buses between cities.

customs: Don't eat beef — cows are sacred in Nepal

health.overview: CIWEC Clinic specializes in travelers. Norvic Hospital for emergencies.
health.vaccinations: Hep A, Typhoid. Rabies recommended. Japanese Encephalitis for Terai.
health.altitude: 1,400m Kathmandu (manageable). Treks go 3,000-5,500m — altitude sickness serious.

faq.a: Very safe by South Asian standards. Welcoming culture.
Serious risk above 3,000m. Acclimatize, ascend slowly, know symptoms.
Yes for most popular routes as of recent regulations.
Real. 2015 was devastating. Know hotel evacuation plan.
Chaotic but safe. You'll adjust quickly. Patan is calmer alternative.

cities.name: Mumbai
cities.summary: Mumbai is India's financial capital, Bollywood's home, and a city of extraordinary contrasts. Colaba and Bandra are cosmopolitan. The Gateway of India and dabbawala network are iconic. Safer than Delhi for women but still requires awareness.
cities.quickVerdict: Safer feeling than Delhi. Colaba, Bandra, and South Mumbai are tourist-friendly. Local trains are an experience but intense during rush hour. Street food is legendary. The city has incredible energy.

neighborhoods.name: Colaba / South Mumbai
neighborhoods.description: Gateway of India, Taj Hotel, Leopold Café. Tourist center. Safe during day.

neighborhoods.name: Bandra
neighborhoods.description: Trendy suburb. Best restaurants and nightlife. Bollywood stars live here.

neighborhoods.name: Lower Parel / Worli
neighborhoods.description: Modern area. Converted mills now house restaurants and galleries.

neighborhoods.name: Fort / Churchgate
neighborhoods.description: Colonial architecture. CST station UNESCO site. Safe during day.

neighborhoods.name: Dharavi
neighborhoods.description: Famous slum. Only with reputable tour operator. People are proud and welcoming.

neighborhoods.name: Outer suburbs
neighborhoods.description: Vast. Mixed safety. Little tourist interest.

scams.name: Taxi Meter Tricks
scams.description: Auto-rickshaws and taxis refuse meter or use outdated rate cards.
scams.howToAvoid: Uber or Ola. Or insist on meter with current fare chart.

scams.name: Tour Touts at Gateway
scams.description: Aggressive tour offers at Gateway of India. Overpriced boat trips.
scams.howToAvoid: Book Elephanta Island ferry at official booth. Ignore touts.

scams.name: Fake Bollywood Extra Scams
scams.description: Offered a 'role' in a Bollywood film. Leads to payment requests.
scams.howToAvoid: No legitimate casting happens on the street.

scams.name: Train Compartment Theft
scams.description: Bags stolen from overhead racks on trains.
scams.howToAvoid: Lock bags to rack. Keep valuables on person. Stay alert.

soloFemale.overview: Better than Delhi for solo women. Mumbai's cosmopolitan culture and late-night food scene make it more comfortable. Local women are out at all hours. Still requires precautions.
tips: Safer feeling than Delhi for women
Local trains have women's compartments — use them during rush hour
Mumbai's street food is a must — try vada pav

nightSafety.overview: Mumbai has excellent nightlife. Bandra and Lower Parel have great bars and restaurants. Marine Drive is atmospheric. Safer than Delhi at night.
tips: Mumbai stays alive later than most Indian cities

transport.metro: Local trains are lifeline of Mumbai. Crowded but essential. Women's compartments available.
transport.taxis: Black-and-yellow taxis iconic. Insist on meter. Uber preferred.
transport.tips: Local trains experience but intense. Uber for comfort. Avoid rush hour trains 8-10am, 5-7pm.

customs: Mumbai is India's most cosmopolitan city
Diverse — Hindu, Muslim, Parsi, Christian communities
Don't touch food with left hand
Dabbawala lunch delivery system is a marvel

health.overview: Breach Candy and Lilavati excellent private hospitals.
health.vaccinations: Same as Delhi — Hep A, Typhoid essential.
health.altitude: Sea level. Monsoon June-September brings flooding. Extreme humidity.

faq.a: Safer than Delhi. Colaba and Bandra comfortable.
Essential Mumbai experience. Women's compartments during rush hour. Intense.
Some of the best in India. Eat where locals eat.
Ethical if with reputable operators. Photography etiquette important.
June-September. City floods. Avoid if possible.

cities.name: Paris
cities.summary: Paris is one of the most visited cities on Earth — and pickpockets know it. Violent crime against tourists is rare, but petty theft is an industry. The Metro, major landmarks, and tourist-heavy neighborhoods are prime hunting grounds for professional pickpocket teams. Beyond that, Paris is a safe, well-policed city with excellent infrastructure.
cities.quickVerdict: Paris is safe for tourists with basic awareness. Your biggest threats are pickpockets at the Eiffel Tower, Louvre, and on the Metro — not violent crime. Keep valuables in front pockets, be skeptical of strangers approaching you with petitions or gold rings, and avoid the northern suburbs. The city's public transit is world-class and generally safe.

neighborhoods.name: Le Marais (3rd/4th arr.)
neighborhoods.description: One of the trendiest and safest areas. Great restaurants, nightlife, and shopping. Popular with the LGBTQ+ community. Safe day and night on main streets. Pickpockets operate near Place des Vosges.

neighborhoods.name: Saint-Germain (6th arr.)
neighborhoods.description: Classic Parisian charm. Upscale, safe, beautiful architecture. Cafés, bookshops, and galleries. One of the safest areas in Paris. Very comfortable for solo travelers.

neighborhoods.name: Montmartre (18th arr.)
neighborhoods.description: The Sacré-Cœur area is tourist-heavy and safe by day but crawling with scammers — bracelet sellers, petition scammers, and three-card monte. The streets below the hill get rougher, especially around Pigalle and Barbès after dark.

neighborhoods.name: Champs-Élysées (8th arr.)
neighborhoods.description: Iconic avenue, heavily policed, safe for walking. Very touristy and overpriced. Pickpockets work the crowds, especially near the Arc de Triomphe. Safe at night due to heavy foot traffic and police.

neighborhoods.name: Latin Quarter (5th arr.)
neighborhoods.description: Student area around the Sorbonne. Lively, safe, affordable restaurants. Charming narrow streets. Safe at night in the main areas. Rue Mouffetard is a highlight.

neighborhoods.name: La Chapelle / Gare du Nord (10th/18th arr.)
neighborhoods.description: The area immediately around Gare du Nord and La Chapelle is the sketchiest in central Paris. Drug dealing, aggressive panhandlers, and pickpockets. Transit through quickly, don't linger. Avoid at night.

scams.name: Petition / Clipboard Scam
scams.description: Groups of young women approach you with clipboards asking you to sign a petition for deaf/mute charity. While you're distracted signing, accomplices pick your pockets. Or they demand a 'donation' after you sign.
scams.howToAvoid: Never stop for clipboard-wielding strangers. A firm 'non' and keep walking. They operate heavily around the Eiffel Tower, Sacré-Cœur, and Louvre.

scams.name: Gold Ring Scam
scams.description: Someone 'finds' a gold ring on the ground near you and offers it as a gift. Then they ask for money as a finder's fee or reward. The ring is worthless brass.
scams.howToAvoid: Ignore anyone who approaches you with a found ring. Don't engage, just walk away.

scams.name: Three-Card Monte
scams.description: Shell game operators set up near Sacré-Cœur and other tourist spots. The crowd around them includes accomplices who pretend to win. You cannot win — it's rigged.
scams.howToAvoid: Never play. Don't even stop to watch — pickpockets work the crowd of spectators.

scams.name: Bracelet / String Scam
scams.description: Men near Sacré-Cœur grab your wrist and tie a friendship bracelet on before you can refuse. Then they aggressively demand payment (€20-40).
scams.howToAvoid: Keep your hands in your pockets when walking up to Sacré-Cœur. If someone reaches for your hand, pull away immediately and say 'non' firmly.

soloFemale.overview: Paris is generally safe for solo female travelers — millions visit every year without incident. Catcalling exists but is less aggressive than in southern Europe or Latin America. The Metro is safe during normal hours. Some neighborhoods feel less comfortable at night.
tips: Le Marais, Saint-Germain, and the Latin Quarter are the most comfortable areas for solo women
The Metro is safe but be alert for pickpockets — keep bags zipped and in front of you
Avoid Gare du Nord area, Pigalle, and Barbès alone after dark
Parisian café culture makes it easy and comfortable to dine alone
If harassed, duck into any shop or café — staff will help
Download the Citymapper app for easy Metro navigation

nightSafety.overview: Central Paris is generally safe at night. The Marais, Saint-Germain, and Bastille areas are lively until late. The Champs-Élysées stays busy. Northern neighborhoods (18th, 19th arrondissements) are less comfortable after dark.
tips: Central arrondissements (1st through 7th) are safe to walk at night
Avoid Gare du Nord, La Chapelle, and Stalingrad areas after dark
The Metro runs until about 1am (2am on Friday/Saturday) and is generally safe
Night buses (Noctilien) are available but less comfortable — use Uber late at night
Montmartre's lower streets (Pigalle area) have aggressive touts for cabarets and sex shops

transport.metro: The Paris Metro is excellent — 16 lines covering the entire city. Clean, frequent, and cheap. Buy a Navigo Easy card or use contactless payment. Watch for pickpockets, especially on Line 1 and crowded trains. Safe overall.
transport.rideshare: Uber and Bolt operate throughout Paris. More expensive than the Metro but convenient for late nights or heavy luggage. Always verify the driver and car match the app.
transport.taxis: Official Parisian taxis (with the roof light) are metered and regulated. Safe and reliable. Don't accept rides from unofficial drivers at airports — use the official taxi stand or order via the FreeNow app.
transport.tips: The Metro is your best option for almost everything. Uber for late nights. Vélib' bike-share is excellent for daytime exploration if you're comfortable cycling in traffic.

customs: Always greet shopkeepers with 'bonjour' when entering and 'au revoir' when leaving — this is not optional
French service style is different from American — waiters won't hover. Get their attention with 'excusez-moi' or eye contact
Tipping: service is included in the bill. Rounding up or leaving 5-10% for excellent service is appreciated but not required
Dress relatively well — Parisians notice sloppy clothing. You don't need to be fashionable, just put-together
Speak a few words of French before defaulting to English — the effort is appreciated even if your French is terrible
Don't talk loudly in restaurants or on the Metro — Parisians value quiet public behavior

health.overview: Paris has world-class healthcare. Public hospitals (Hôpital Pitié-Salpêtrière, Hôpital Européen Georges-Pompidou) are excellent. EU citizens can use EHIC cards. Non-EU visitors need travel insurance.
health.water: Tap water is perfectly safe and high quality. Free water ('une carafe d'eau') is available at all restaurants by law.
health.vaccinations: No specific vaccinations required for Paris. Routine vaccines should be up to date.
health.altitude: No altitude concerns. Air quality can be poor on hot summer days — check forecasts if you have respiratory conditions.

faq.q: Is Paris safe for tourists in 2026?
faq.a: Yes, Paris is safe with standard precautions. Violent crime against tourists is rare. Pickpockets are your main concern, especially at landmarks and on the Metro. Keep valuables secure and be wary of common scams.
Yes, the Metro is safe and efficient. Pickpockets operate on crowded lines (especially Line 1), so keep bags zipped and valuables in front pockets. Late at night, stick to busier stations.

faq.q: Which areas of Paris should I avoid?
faq.a: Avoid the area around Gare du Nord, La Chapelle, and parts of the 18th and 19th arrondissements at night. During the day, these areas are fine to transit through but not ideal for wandering.

faq.q: Is Paris safe for solo female travelers?
faq.a: Yes, Paris is one of the safer major European cities for solo women. Central neighborhoods are comfortable day and night. Standard precautions on the Metro and avoiding certain northern areas after dark.

faq.q: Do I need to tip in Paris?
faq.a: Service is included in all restaurant bills by law. Leaving a few euros for exceptional service is appreciated but not expected. You don't need to tip taxi drivers but rounding up is common.

cities.name: Rome
cities.summary: Rome is chaotic, beautiful, and generally safe. Violent crime against tourists is extremely rare — pickpockets and scammers are the real threats. The historic center is well-policed and safe to walk day and night. The city's public transport is functional but crowded, creating opportunities for thieves. Most visitors have wonderful, incident-free trips.
cities.quickVerdict: Rome is safe for tourists who protect their belongings. The Colosseum, Vatican, and Trastevere are all safe to explore. Your main risks are pickpockets on buses and the Metro, overcharging at restaurants near tourist sites, and the occasional gladiator photo scam. Use common sense with your valuables and you'll be fine.

neighborhoods.name: Centro Storico
neighborhoods.description: The historic heart — Pantheon, Piazza Navona, Trevi Fountain. Heavily touristed and well-policed. Safe day and night. Pickpockets operate in crowds. Restaurants nearest to landmarks are tourist traps with inflated prices.

neighborhoods.name: Trastevere
neighborhoods.description: Charming cobblestone neighborhood across the Tiber. Excellent restaurants and nightlife. Safe and lively at night. Can get very crowded on weekends. Watch for pickpockets in the busy piazzas.

neighborhoods.name: Vatican / Prati
neighborhoods.description: Safe, upscale residential area near the Vatican. Good restaurants on Via Cola di Rienzo. The area around St. Peter's has aggressive tour touts and souvenir sellers but is physically safe.

neighborhoods.name: Monti
neighborhoods.description: Trendy neighborhood near the Colosseum. Great bars, vintage shops, and local feel. One of the safest and most charming areas in Rome. Increasingly popular with travelers who want authenticity.

neighborhoods.name: Testaccio
neighborhoods.description: Traditional working-class neighborhood turned foodie destination. Authentic Roman cuisine, local nightlife. Safe and not overly touristy. The market is a must-visit.

neighborhoods.name: Termini Station Area
neighborhoods.description: The area immediately around Termini is the least appealing in central Rome. Aggressive panhandlers, pickpockets, and some drug activity. Fine during the day for transit but don't linger. Budget hotels here are cheap for a reason.

scams.name: Gladiator Photo Scam
scams.description: Men dressed as Roman gladiators near the Colosseum pose for photos with tourists, then aggressively demand €20-50 per photo. They can become intimidating in groups.
scams.howToAvoid: Don't pose with the gladiators unless you're willing to pay. If you accidentally do, offer €5 maximum and walk away.

scams.name: Restaurant Tourist Traps
scams.description: Restaurants directly facing major landmarks charge 3-5x normal prices, add hidden 'service charges' and 'coperto' fees, and serve mediocre food. Some have aggressive touts pulling you in.
scams.howToAvoid: Walk at least 2-3 blocks from any major landmark before eating. Check Google reviews. Avoid any restaurant with a tout outside or photos on the menu. Ask locals for recommendations.

scams.name: Pickpockets on Bus 64
scams.description: Bus 64 (Termini to Vatican) is infamous for organized pickpocket teams. They work in groups — one distracts while others reach into bags and pockets. Also common on Metro Line A.
scams.howToAvoid: Keep bags in front of you with zippers closed. Don't put phones in back pockets. Be especially alert when buses are crowded and during boarding/exiting.

scams.name: Fake Designer Goods / Rose Sellers
scams.description: Street vendors sell fake designer bags laid out on sheets. Rose sellers approach couples at restaurants and insist on giving the woman a rose, then demand payment from the man.
scams.howToAvoid: A firm 'no grazie' to rose sellers. Don't accept the rose at all. Fake goods sellers are harmless but buying supports illegal operations.

soloFemale.overview: Rome is generally safe for solo women. Italian men can be persistent with compliments and attention — it's more annoying than threatening. The historic center and popular neighborhoods are comfortable to explore alone. The main risk is the same pickpocketing that affects everyone.
tips: Trastevere, Monti, and the Centro Storico are comfortable for solo women day and night
Italian men may make comments — a firm but polite response or simply ignoring them works
Avoid the Termini station area alone at night
The evening passeggiata (walk) culture means streets stay busy and safe until late
Rome has a very social dining culture — sitting at the bar in trattorias is totally normal for solo travelers
Uber works in Rome but is limited — use the FreeNow app for official taxis

nightSafety.overview: Rome is one of the safer European capitals at night. Italians eat late and socialize late, so streets in popular areas stay lively until midnight or later. The passeggiata culture keeps neighborhoods feeling alive.
tips: Trastevere, Monti, and Campo de' Fiori are great for evening walks and nightlife
The Centro Storico is safe to walk at night — well-lit and well-patrolled
Avoid the Termini station area and Esquilino after dark
Night buses run but are less comfortable — taxis or Uber are better late at night
Parks (Villa Borghese, Colle Oppio) should be avoided after dark

transport.metro: Rome's Metro has just 3 lines and is limited compared to other capitals, but covers the main tourist sites. Crowded during rush hour — prime pickpocket time. Line A (Termini to Vatican) is the most useful for tourists.
transport.rideshare: Uber operates in Rome but only with licensed vehicles (more expensive than regular Uber). FreeNow and itTaxi apps are better for getting official taxis. Always use apps rather than hailing on the street.
transport.taxis: Official white taxis are metered and regulated. Fixed fares exist for airport transfers (€50 from Fiumicino to city center). Only use taxis from official stands or apps. Unofficial drivers at airports will overcharge.
transport.tips: Rome is best explored on foot — the historic center is compact and walkable. Buses are useful but pickpocket-heavy. Taxis for longer distances or late nights.

customs: Dress modestly when visiting churches — covered shoulders and knees are required at the Vatican and most churches
Italians greet with two kisses on the cheek (left then right) once they know you
Tipping: a small service charge (coperto) is included. Leaving a few euros extra for good service is appreciated
Dinner is late — most restaurants don't fill up until 8:30-9pm. Don't eat at 6pm or you'll be dining alone in a tourist trap
Coffee culture: cappuccino is a breakfast drink only. Ordering one after lunch earns mild judgment. Espresso is the afternoon choice
Don't sit on historic monuments or fountains — Rome enforces fines for sitting on the Spanish Steps and similar sites

health.overview: Rome has good public healthcare. Policlinico Umberto I and Ospedale Fatebenefratelli are central. EU citizens can use EHIC. Travel insurance essential for non-EU visitors. Pharmacies (marked with green crosses) can provide many medications without prescriptions.
health.water: Tap water is safe and excellent. Rome's many public drinking fountains (nasoni) provide fresh, clean water — bring a reusable bottle and refill everywhere.
health.vaccinations: No specific vaccinations required. Routine vaccines should be up to date.
health.altitude: No altitude concerns. Summer heat is the main health factor — temperatures regularly exceed 35°C (95°F) in July and August. Stay hydrated and seek shade midday.

faq.a: Yes, Rome is safe. Violent crime against tourists is very rare. Pickpocketing is the main risk, concentrated at tourist sites and on public transport. Keep valuables secure and be wary of common scams.
Physically safe, but pickpockets are active on crowded trains, especially Line A. Keep bags in front, zipped, and be alert during boarding and exiting. Off-peak times are less risky.
Yes, Trastevere is one of the best neighborhoods for nightlife and evening dining. Streets are lively and well-lit until late. Standard precautions with valuables apply.

faq.q: Should I avoid any areas in Rome?
faq.a: The area immediately around Termini station is the least comfortable part of central Rome, especially at night. The suburbs of Tor Bella Monaca and San Basilio are best avoided entirely.

faq.q: Is tap water safe in Rome?
faq.a: Yes, Rome's tap water is excellent. The public drinking fountains (nasoni) found throughout the city provide fresh, clean water. Bring a reusable bottle.

cities.name: Prague
cities.summary: Prague is one of the safest capital cities in Europe. Violent crime is extremely rare, and the biggest risks are tourist-targeting scams, overpriced exchange offices, and pickpockets in Old Town Square. The city is compact, walkable, and has excellent public transit. It's an ideal destination for first-time European travelers.
cities.quickVerdict: Prague is very safe. Your main risks are currency exchange scams, overpriced restaurants in Old Town, and pickpockets at major tourist sites. Use ATMs instead of exchange offices, eat a few blocks from Old Town Square, and keep valuables secured. The rest is easy — Prague is friendly, affordable, and well-organized.

neighborhoods.name: Old Town (Staré Město)
neighborhoods.description: Tourist epicenter — Charles Bridge, Astronomical Clock, Old Town Square. Very safe but heavy with scammers and overpriced restaurants. Pickpockets work the crowds. Beautiful but explore beyond it too.

neighborhoods.name: Malá Strana
neighborhoods.description: Charming neighborhood below Prague Castle. Quiet cobblestone streets, embassies, and gardens. Very safe day and night. Less crowded than Old Town but equally beautiful.

neighborhoods.name: Vinohrady
neighborhoods.description: Leafy residential neighborhood popular with expats. Excellent restaurants and bars, very safe, less touristy. One of the best areas to stay for a local experience. Beautiful parks and Art Nouveau architecture.

neighborhoods.name: Žižkov
neighborhoods.description: Formerly rough, now gentrifying with great bars and nightlife. Safe but grittier feel than other neighborhoods. The TV Tower is a landmark. Good budget accommodation.

neighborhoods.name: Holešovice
neighborhoods.description: Up-and-coming neighborhood with galleries, craft breweries, and markets. DOX art center is a highlight. Safe and increasingly trendy. Great for travelers who want an alternative vibe.

neighborhoods.name: Wenceslas Square (lower end)
neighborhoods.description: The lower end near nightclubs can get rowdy after midnight — aggressive touts for strip clubs, overpriced tourist traps, and occasional pickpocketing. Fine during the day, just chaotic at night on weekends.

scams.name: Currency Exchange Rip-off
scams.description: Exchange offices in tourist areas offer terrible rates with hidden fees and commissions. Some advertise '0% commission' but have a massive spread between buy/sell rates. You can lose 20-30% of your money.
scams.howToAvoid: Never use street exchange offices. Use ATMs to withdraw Czech Koruna (CZK) with your bank card. If you must exchange, check the rate online first and confirm the total amount you'll receive before handing over money.

scams.name: Overpriced Old Town Restaurants
scams.description: Restaurants directly on Old Town Square charge 3-5x normal Prague prices. Some have different prices for tourists and locals, or add items to your bill that you didn't order.
scams.howToAvoid: Walk 5 minutes from Old Town Square in any direction for much better prices and food. Check the bill carefully. Ask for prices before ordering if there's no visible menu.

scams.name: Taxi Overcharging
scams.description: Some taxi drivers take long routes or use rigged meters. Airport taxis are the worst offenders. Fair price from the airport to center should be 600-800 CZK.
scams.howToAvoid: Use Bolt or Uber — much more reliable than street taxis. If using a taxi, agree on the price before getting in or insist on the meter.

scams.name: Strip Club Scams
scams.description: Touts near Wenceslas Square lure tourists (usually men) to strip clubs with promises of free entry or cheap drinks. Inside, drinks cost hundreds of euros. Bouncers prevent you from leaving without paying.
scams.howToAvoid: Never follow a tout to a club. Choose your own venues. If you end up in a scam club, pay what's reasonable, take photos of the bill, and file a police report.

soloFemale.overview: Prague is one of the safest European cities for solo female travelers. Czech culture is reserved and respectful. Street harassment is uncommon. The city is compact and easy to navigate. Many solo women rate Prague as one of their favorite and most comfortable destinations.
tips: Prague is excellent for solo women — low street harassment, safe public transport, and welcoming culture
Vinohrady and Malá Strana are the most comfortable neighborhoods
The Metro and trams are safe even late at night
The lower end of Wenceslas Square gets rowdy on weekend nights — avoid the club touts
Prague has a thriving café culture — solo dining is completely normal and comfortable
Join a free walking tour on your first day to orient yourself and meet other travelers

nightSafety.overview: Prague is safe at night in most areas. Old Town stays lively until late, and Žižkov and Vinohrady have excellent bar scenes. The main issue is the rowdy stag party crowd on weekends in the center.
tips: Old Town, Malá Strana, and Vinohrady are safe to walk at night
Lower Wenceslas Square gets rowdy on Friday/Saturday nights — avoid strip club touts
Trams run 24 hours — night trams are safe and useful
Prague has a huge stag/hen party scene — the center can feel chaotic on weekend nights
Bolt and Uber are reliable for late-night transport

transport.metro: Prague's Metro has 3 lines and is clean, efficient, and very safe. Combined with the excellent tram network, it covers the entire city. Buy a travel pass for unlimited rides. Validate your ticket or face a 1,500 CZK fine.
transport.rideshare: Bolt and Uber both operate well in Prague. Cheaper and more reliable than traditional taxis. Use these instead of hailing taxis on the street.
transport.taxis: Licensed taxis have yellow rooftop signs. AAA Taxi and Tick Tack are reputable companies. Avoid unmarked taxis and anyone who approaches you offering a ride.
transport.tips: The tram network is fantastic — scenic and connects everywhere. Night trams (numbers 91-99) run every 30 minutes after midnight. The Metro closes around midnight.

customs: Czech people are reserved initially but warm once you connect — don't mistake quietness for unfriendliness
Always say 'dobrý den' (hello) when entering shops and restaurants
Tipping: round up or add 10% at restaurants. Leave the tip in cash on the table even if paying by card
Beer is a cultural institution — Czech beer is excellent and cheaper than water in many places
Don't confuse Czech Republic with Slovakia — they've been separate countries since 1993
Czech cuisine is hearty (pork, dumplings, sauerkraut) — vegetarians should check menus carefully

health.overview: Prague has good healthcare. Nemocnice Na Homolce is the recommended hospital for foreigners with English-speaking staff. EU citizens can use EHIC. Travel insurance recommended for non-EU visitors.
health.water: Tap water is safe to drink throughout Prague.
health.vaccinations: No specific vaccinations required. Routine vaccines should be up to date. Tick-borne encephalitis vaccine recommended if you plan to hike in forested areas outside the city.
health.altitude: No altitude concerns. Prague has relatively mild weather year-round.

faq.a: Yes, Prague is one of the safest capitals in Europe. Violent crime is extremely rare. Pickpocketing and tourist scams are the only real concerns, and both are easily avoided.
Yes, most areas are safe at night. Lower Wenceslas Square can get rowdy on weekends due to the stag party scene. Avoid strip club touts. Night trams are safe and reliable.

faq.q: Should I exchange money at exchange offices?
faq.a: No. Many exchange offices in tourist areas have terrible rates. Use ATMs to withdraw Czech Koruna (CZK) directly. This gives you the best exchange rate.

faq.q: Is Prague safe for solo female travelers?
faq.a: Very safe. Prague consistently ranks among the best European cities for solo women. Low harassment, safe transport, compact city center, and a respectful culture.

faq.q: Can I use euros in Prague?
faq.a: Some tourist places accept euros but give terrible exchange rates. Czech Koruna (CZK) is the currency — use ATMs to withdraw it. Card payments are widely accepted.

cities.name: Berlin
cities.summary: Berlin is a sprawling, alternative, and remarkably safe major city. Violent crime is rare, especially in areas tourists visit. The city has world-famous nightlife, incredible history, and a tolerant, progressive culture. Petty crime exists — mainly bike theft and pickpocketing at tourist sites — but overall, Berlin is one of Europe's safest capitals.
cities.quickVerdict: Berlin is very safe for tourists. There's no area in central Berlin that's genuinely dangerous. Pickpockets operate at major sites (Brandenburg Gate, Alexanderplatz) and on the U-Bahn. The famous nightlife scene is safe if you exercise normal precautions. Berlin is extremely welcoming to all travelers.

neighborhoods.name: Mitte
neighborhoods.description: Central Berlin — Brandenburg Gate, Museum Island, Checkpoint Charlie. Tourist-heavy, well-policed, safe day and night. Pickpockets at Alexanderplatz. Restaurants near the Gate are tourist traps — walk a few blocks.

neighborhoods.name: Kreuzberg
neighborhoods.description: Alternative, multicultural, vibrant. Best food scene in Berlin. Parts feel gritty but are safe. Görlitzer Park has open drug dealing but it's non-threatening. Great nightlife around Kottbusser Tor.

neighborhoods.name: Prenzlauer Berg
neighborhoods.description: Gentrified, family-friendly, beautiful. Tree-lined streets, brunch culture, boutique shopping. One of the safest areas. Very comfortable for all travelers. Mauerpark flea market is a Sunday highlight.

neighborhoods.name: Friedrichshain
neighborhoods.description: Young, alternative, great nightlife. The East Side Gallery is here. RAW Gelände area has clubs and street art. Safe but watch belongings at night around the club areas. Warschauer Straße station can feel edgy late at night.

neighborhoods.name: Charlottenburg
neighborhoods.description: West Berlin's elegant heart. Kurfürstendamm shopping street, excellent restaurants, quiet residential areas. Very safe and upscale. Good base for travelers who prefer a calmer atmosphere.

neighborhoods.name: Alexanderplatz
neighborhoods.description: Major transit hub. The square itself is safe but attracts pickpockets, hustlers, and can feel chaotic. Fine for visiting the TV Tower and sightseeing. Don't linger unnecessarily, especially late at night.

scams.name: Club Door Scams
scams.description: Some clubs charge high cover fees then serve watered-down drinks. Fake promoters hand out flyers for 'free entry' clubs that hit you with minimum spend requirements once inside.
scams.howToAvoid: Research clubs before going. Berlin's best clubs (Berghain, Tresor, Watergate) don't need promoters. Avoid anyone handing out club flyers on the street.

scams.name: Pickpockets at Tourist Sites
scams.description: Professional pickpockets work Brandenburg Gate, Alexanderplatz, and crowded U-Bahn trains. Common techniques include distraction (asking for directions, showing a map) while accomplices pick pockets.
scams.howToAvoid: Keep valuables in front pockets or a money belt. Be alert when anyone approaches you at tourist sites. Backpacks are easy targets — wear across the front in crowds.

scams.name: Fake Ticket Inspectors
scams.description: Rare but reported — people claiming to be BVG inspectors demanding on-the-spot fines. Real inspectors show ID and won't ask for cash directly.
scams.howToAvoid: Always validate your ticket. Real inspectors wear ID badges and will direct you to official payment. If unsure, ask to see official identification.

scams.name: Dropped Currency Trick
scams.description: Someone drops coins or bills near you and asks for help picking them up. While you're distracted, an accomplice picks your pocket.
scams.howToAvoid: Be aware of your surroundings when strangers approach. Don't let distractions take your attention from your belongings.

soloFemale.overview: Berlin is excellent for solo female travelers. The city has a strong culture of tolerance and progressive values. Street harassment is much less common than in southern European cities. The nightlife scene is inclusive and respectful. Many solo women consider Berlin one of the most comfortable European cities to travel alone.
tips: Berlin is one of Europe's most comfortable cities for solo women — low harassment and progressive culture
Prenzlauer Berg, Charlottenburg, and Mitte are the most comfortable areas
Public transport is safe even late at night — Berlin's nightlife means trains run all night on weekends
The club scene has a strong consent culture — bouncers take harassment seriously
Görlitzer Park in Kreuzberg is fine during the day but avoid walking through alone at night
Berlin has many co-working spaces and social hostels that are great for meeting other solo travelers

nightSafety.overview: Berlin has one of the world's best nightlife scenes and is remarkably safe for it. Clubs stay open until morning (or through the weekend). Public transport runs 24 hours on weekends. Most areas are safe to walk at night.
tips: Central Berlin is safe to walk at night in most areas
The U-Bahn and S-Bahn run all night on Friday and Saturday — safe and convenient
Warschauer Straße area can feel edgy late at night — keep aware of your surroundings
Görlitzer Park should be avoided after dark
Berlin's club culture means streets in Kreuzberg and Friedrichshain have foot traffic all night on weekends

transport.metro: Berlin's public transport (BVG) is excellent — U-Bahn (subway), S-Bahn (commuter rail), trams, and buses cover the entire city. Buy an AB zone day pass. Validate your ticket — inspectors are frequent and the €60 fine is enforced.
transport.rideshare: Uber operates but is more expensive than in other cities. Bolt is also available. For most trips, public transport is faster and cheaper.
transport.taxis: Cream-colored taxis are metered and reliable. The Kurzstrecke (short trip) fare of €6 applies for trips up to 2km if you hail one on the street. Taxi apps: FreeNow works well.
transport.tips: Public transport is king in Berlin. Get the BVG app for route planning and mobile tickets. Biking is very popular — Berlin is flat and has excellent bike infrastructure.

customs: Germans are direct — don't mistake bluntness for rudeness. It's just communication style
Cash is still king in many Berlin restaurants and shops — always carry some euros
Tipping: round up or add 5-10%. Tell the server the total amount you're paying when they bring the bill
Sundays are quiet — most shops are closed by law. Stock up on Saturday. Restaurants and museums are open
Don't jaywalk — Germans wait for the green man even if there's no traffic. Especially don't jaywalk around children
Berlin's nightclub culture has a 'no photos' policy inside clubs — respect it or you'll be asked to leave

health.overview: Berlin has excellent healthcare. Charité is one of Europe's largest and most respected hospitals. EU citizens can use EHIC. Non-EU visitors should have travel insurance. Pharmacies (Apotheke) are easy to find.
health.water: Tap water is safe and high quality throughout Berlin.
health.vaccinations: No specific vaccinations required. Routine vaccines should be up to date.
health.altitude: No altitude concerns. Berlin is flat and at low elevation. Summers can get hot (35°C+) and winters cold (-10°C) — dress appropriately.

faq.a: Yes, Berlin is one of Europe's safest major cities. Violent crime is rare in tourist areas. Pickpocketing at major sites and on public transport is the main concern.
Yes, Berlin is remarkably safe at night. Public transport runs 24 hours on weekends. Most central neighborhoods are safe to walk. Görlitzer Park should be avoided after dark.
Yes, Kreuzberg is safe despite its gritty appearance. It's Berlin's most multicultural and foodie-friendly neighborhood. Görlitzer Park has open drug dealing but it's non-confrontational.

faq.q: Is Berlin safe for solo female travelers?
faq.a: Excellent. Berlin has progressive values, low street harassment, and a strong consent culture in its nightlife scene. Many solo women rank it as their most comfortable European destination.

faq.q: Do I need cash in Berlin?
faq.a: Yes, more than you'd expect. Many restaurants, bars, and smaller shops are cash-only. Always carry some euros. ATMs are widely available.

cities.name: Lisbon
cities.summary: Lisbon is one of Europe's safest capital cities and an increasingly popular destination. Violent crime is very rare, and the main risks are pickpocketing on trams and in tourist areas, and the occasional restaurant scam. The city is hilly, beautiful, affordable (by Western European standards), and extremely welcoming to visitors.
cities.quickVerdict: Lisbon is very safe. Your biggest risks are pickpockets on Tram 28 and in the Alfama, and restaurants in tourist areas that add unwanted items to your table (then charge for them). The city is walkable (if you don't mind hills), has great public transit, and Portuguese people are genuinely warm and helpful.

neighborhoods.name: Baixa / Chiado
neighborhoods.description: Downtown Lisbon. Wide streets, shops, and the famous Rossio square. Tourist-heavy, well-policed. Pickpockets work the crowds. Great central location but can feel commercial. Safe day and night.

neighborhoods.name: Alfama
neighborhoods.description: The old Moorish quarter — narrow winding streets, fado houses, São Jorge Castle. Charming and safe by day. Can feel isolated in the narrow alleys after midnight. Pickpockets on Tram 28 as it passes through.

neighborhoods.name: Príncipe Real / Bairro Alto
neighborhoods.description: Trendy area by day (boutiques, cafés, gardens), nightlife hub after dark. Bairro Alto's narrow streets fill with bar-hoppers on weekends. Safe but gets rowdy late. Príncipe Real is quieter and upscale.

neighborhoods.name: Santos / Cais do Sodré
neighborhoods.description: Riverside area with Time Out Market and the Pink Street nightlife strip. Lively and fun. Safe but watch belongings in the crowded market and during weekend nightlife.

neighborhoods.name: Belém
neighborhoods.description: Historic neighborhood with Jerónimos Monastery and the Tower of Belém. Residential, quiet, very safe. Pastéis de Belém is a must-visit. Further from the center but worth the tram ride.

neighborhoods.name: Mouraria
neighborhoods.description: Multicultural neighborhood adjacent to Alfama. Rapidly gentrifying with great restaurants but still has rougher edges. Drug activity in some alleys. Fine during the day, less comfortable at night in the back streets.

scams.name: Tram 28 Pickpockets
scams.description: Tram 28 is Lisbon's most famous tourist attraction — and pickpocket teams know it. The tram is always packed and the crowds create perfect cover. Organized groups board at key stops and target tourists.
scams.howToAvoid: Walk the Tram 28 route instead (it's beautiful on foot). If you ride, hold bags in front, keep pockets zipped, and be alert when people push past you. Consider riding early morning when it's less crowded.

scams.name: Unwanted Appetizers Scam
scams.description: Restaurants place bread, butter, olives, cheese, and other items on your table when you sit down. They're not free — each item is added to your bill (€3-8 per item). It looks like a complimentary welcome.
scams.howToAvoid: If you didn't order it, ask 'is this included?' or simply tell the waiter to take it away. You're not obligated to keep or pay for unrequested items.

scams.name: Drug Dealers in Bairro Alto / Rossio
scams.description: Men approach tourists whispering offers to sell marijuana or cocaine, particularly around Rossio square and in Bairro Alto at night. The drugs are often fake (oregano or similar) and buying puts you at risk.
scams.howToAvoid: Just ignore them and keep walking. A simple 'no' is enough. Don't engage in conversation. They're persistent but not threatening.

scams.name: Tuk-Tuk Overcharging
scams.description: Lisbon's tuk-tuks are fun but often massively overpriced. Drivers quote inflated prices to tourists, especially near major landmarks. A tuk-tuk tour can cost €80-150 for what should be €30-40.
scams.howToAvoid: Agree on a fixed price before getting in. Compare prices with multiple drivers. Better yet, book through a reputable tour company online rather than hiring off the street.

soloFemale.overview: Lisbon is excellent for solo female travelers. Portuguese culture is warm and respectful, and street harassment is uncommon. The city has a thriving solo travel scene, many social hostels, and a walkable center that feels safe and comfortable.
tips: Lisbon is very comfortable for solo women — one of the safest cities in Western Europe
Baixa, Chiado, and Príncipe Real are the most comfortable neighborhoods
Portuguese people are genuinely helpful — don't hesitate to ask for directions
Bairro Alto nightlife is busy and social — easy to meet people, and the crowd provides safety in numbers
Mouraria back streets are less comfortable alone at night
The city's many viewpoints (miradouros) are safe and beautiful — great for solo experiences

nightSafety.overview: Lisbon has vibrant nightlife and is generally safe after dark. Bairro Alto and Cais do Sodré are the main nightlife areas, packed with people on weekends. The well-lit downtown (Baixa) is safe to walk through at night.
tips: Bairro Alto and Pink Street (Cais do Sodré) are the safest nightlife areas — lots of people around
Alfama's narrow alleys can feel isolated after midnight — stick to the main streets
Mouraria back streets are best avoided at night
The Metro runs until 1am — after that, use Uber or Bolt
Watch for pickpockets in busy nightlife areas, especially Bairro Alto on weekends

transport.metro: Lisbon's Metro is clean, safe, and efficient but doesn't cover all tourist areas. Four lines with good coverage of the center. Runs from 6:30am to 1am. Get a Viva Viagem card for all public transport.
transport.rideshare: Uber and Bolt are cheap and widely available in Lisbon — often better than taxis. Great for late nights and reaching hilly areas.
transport.taxis: Cream-colored taxis are metered and generally honest. Insist on the meter. Airport to center should be €15-20 with the meter. Official taxi stands are outside the airport arrivals.
transport.tips: Lisbon is hilly — very hilly. Wear good shoes. The Metro, trams, and elevadores (funiculars) help with the steep climbs. Uber is great for getting up the hills when you're tired.

customs: Portuguese people are warm and hospitable — greet with 'bom dia' (morning) or 'boa tarde' (afternoon)
Coffee culture is strong — order a 'bica' for espresso in Lisbon (not 'café')
Tipping: not expected but appreciated. Round up or leave 5-10% for good service
Meal times are later than Northern Europe — lunch at 1pm, dinner at 8-9pm
Portuguese people speak excellent English but always try a few Portuguese words — they appreciate the effort
Don't compare Portugal to Spain — Portuguese national identity is distinct and proud

health.overview: Lisbon has good healthcare. Hospital de Santa Maria and CUF Descobertas (private) are well-regarded. EU citizens can use EHIC. Travel insurance recommended for non-EU visitors.
health.water: Tap water is safe to drink throughout Lisbon, though some people prefer bottled for taste.
health.vaccinations: No specific vaccinations required. Routine vaccines should be up to date.
health.altitude: No altitude concerns. Lisbon is coastal. The hills can be physically demanding in summer heat — stay hydrated and take breaks.

faq.a: Yes, Lisbon is one of Europe's safest capitals. Violent crime against tourists is very rare. Pickpocketing and minor scams are the only real concerns, mainly on Tram 28 and in tourist-heavy areas.
Physically safe, but it's the top pickpocketing spot in Lisbon. The extreme crowding makes it easy for thieves. Consider walking the route instead, or riding early morning when it's quieter.

faq.q: Is Bairro Alto safe at night?
faq.a: Yes, Bairro Alto is Lisbon's main nightlife area and is safe with the usual precautions. Streets are packed with people on Thursday-Saturday nights. Watch your belongings in crowds.

faq.q: Is Lisbon safe for solo female travelers?
faq.a: Very safe. Portuguese culture is respectful, street harassment is low, and the city has a strong solo travel scene. Many solo women rate Lisbon as one of their top European destinations.

faq.q: Is the water safe to drink in Lisbon?
faq.a: Yes, tap water is safe throughout Lisbon. Some people prefer bottled water for taste, but the tap water meets all EU quality standards.
